MIAMI Donald Trump on Friday called for disarming the bodyguards who protect his Democratic rival Hillary Clinton
column2: and mused about the consequences of such a move by saying ""Let's see what happens to her.""    The Republican presidential nominee was speaking at a rally in Miami
column3: where he contrasted his supporters
column4: who he said back police and want crime reduced
column6: who he derided as someone who ""lives behind walls and raises money from hedge funds.""""I think that her bodyguards should drop all weapons. They should disarm. I think they should disarm immediately
column10: she doesn't want guns. Take them
column11: let's see what happens to her. Take their guns away
column12: okay. It will be very dangerous.""Both candidates have been protected by the Secret Service for months

column15: Donald Trump once again alluded to violence against Hillary Clinton

column1: This is a truly deplorable comment that betrays our nation's most fundamental democratic values

column4: a comment some interpreted as encouraging a political assassination.""If she gets to pick her judges
column6: Trump told a rally in North Carolina on Aug. 9. ""Although the Second Amendment people

column5: Mook said in a statement.     (Reporting by Emily Stephenson; Writing by Eric Walsh; Editing by Mary Milliken)"

column1: 1	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-cuba-idUSKCN11M2IF	Trump would undo Obama's Cuba moves unless religious freedom allowed	"

MIAMI Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump said on Friday that if elected he would seek to reverse President Barack Obama's moves to open relations with Cuba unless the leaders there allowed religious freedoms and freed political prisoners. ""The next president can reverse them
column2: and that I will do unless the Castro regime meets our demands
column3: Trump said at a rally in Miami
column4: which has a large Cuban population.

column1: (Reporting by Emily Stephenson; Editing by Leslie Adler)"
2	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-idUSKCN11M1F3	Trump finally backs off Obama birth claim
column2: falsely says Clinton started it	"

column1: By Steve Holland and Emily Stephenson
| WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump on Friday abandoned his false claim that Barack Obama was not born in the United States after spending five years peddling conspiracy theories that the country's first African-American president started life as a foreigner.But
column2: never one to let a controversy go without fanning its flames
column3: Trump accused Hillary Clinton
column4: his Democratic rival in the Nov. 8 election
column5: of starting the so-called birther movement in her failed 2008 presidential campaign against Obama
column6: a claim that does not stand up to scrutiny.Trump
column7: who has won back some ground in opinion polls and made the White House race more competitive after he went through a summer slump
column8: made his announcement in an attempt to clear the air as he prepares for the first of three televised presidential debates with Clinton on Sept. 26.""President Barack Obama was born in the United States. Period
column10: a real estate developer. ""Now we all want to get back to making America strong and great again
column11: he said at an event in Washington at a new Trump International Hotel down the street from the White House.Devoting only about 30 seconds to the subject
column12: Trump did not apologize and did not expand upon his abrupt decision to shift from a stance he held for five years.The New York businessman brought up the birther controversy as far back as 2011
column13: appealing to a right-wing fringe of voters who formed the early base of his support when he launched his presidential bid last year.The birther conspiracy movement is aimed at challenging the legality of Obama's presidency - the U.S Constitution requires that a president be a natural-born citizen.During his presidential campaign
column14: Trump has readily trafficked in other theories that are the stuff of American supermarket tabloids.There was his declaration that the father of U.S. Senator Ted Cruz
column15: one of Trump's many rivals for the Republican nomination
column16: might have been linked to the assassin of President John F. Kennedy. And there was his false claim that thousands of Muslims in Jersey City
column18: cheered when the World Trade Center twin towers collapsed in the Sept. 11
column20: attacks.In making his announcement on Friday
column21: Trump advanced a widely debunked claim that Clinton and her 2008 campaign had been the original birthers.""Hillary Clinton and her campaign of 2008 started the birther controversy. I finished it. You know what I mean
column22: he said.His campaign directed reporters to a 2007 memo from then-Clinton adviser Mark Penn
column23: who had encouraged the Clinton campaign to go negative against Obama by saying that his Hawaiian birth and boyhood in Indonesia gave him limited roots in American values and culture.

column1: Penn eventually left the Clinton campaign
column2: and his advice was never acted upon.    ""A NEW LIE""

column1: The Democratic National Committee on Friday condemned Trump's bid to link Clinton to the birther idea. ""He had the audacity to spout a new lie about the birther movement that he helped to build
column2: it said.Clinton
column3: who leads Trump by 4 percentage points in the latest Reuters/Ipsos poll
column4: on Friday demanded Trump apologize to the president for having helped spread the birther idea and said Trump had tried to ""delegitimize our first black president.""""His campaign was founded on this outrageous lie. There is no erasing it in history
column5: Clinton said in an address to the Black Women's Association in Washington.Clinton seized on the issue after struggling to overcome the fallout from her remark a week ago that half of Trump's supporters are in a ""basket of deplorables"" and her initial secrecy about her pneumonia diagnosis.

column1: Obama
column2: who produced the longer version of his Hawaiian birth certificate in 2011 to prove doubters wrong
column3: had famously mocked Trump over the issue at a White House Correspondents Association dinner as the wealthy businessman sat in the audience fuming.Still
column4: Trump clung to the contention that Obama was foreign-born
column5: tweeting in August 2012: ""An 'extremely credible source' has called my office and told me that @BarackObama's birth certificate is a fraud.""On Friday
column6: Obama was asked for his reaction to the latest Trump declaration.""I'm shocked that a question like that has come up at a time when we have so many other things to do. Well
column7: I'm not that shocked actually. It's fairly typical. We've got other things to attend to
column8: he said. ""I was pretty confident about where I was born.""Trump's embrace of the birther movement has incensed black Americans
column9: whose votes Trump has been trying to court.Members of the Congressional Black Caucus held a news conference on Friday to urge African-American voters to resist any temptation to support Trump.

column1: I'm wondering when this country is going to awaken from this reality show
column2: said Representative Brenda Lawrence
column3: a Democrat.First lady Michelle Obama told a crowd in Fairfax
column4: Virginia
column5: that her husband has set a strong example for those who have doubted ""whether my husband was even born in this country.""""Well
column7: I think Barack has answered those questions with the example he's set: by going high when they go low. And he's answered these questions with the progress that we've achieved together
column8: she said.At a rally in Miami later on Friday
column9: Trump pushed back on the idea that he and his supporters were racist
column10: saying that when Democrats are in trouble politically
column11: ""they always pull out the racist word.""He walked out at the rally to a song from the musical ""Les Miserables"" in front of a backdrop that read ""Les Deplorables
column12: a reference to Clinton's comment last week about his supporters.The issue of Obama's birthplace has not been a factor in the campaign leading up to the November presidential election
column13: but it resurfaced in recent days
column14: taking the focus of Trump's White House bid away from topics such as immigration
column16: which he has been using to hit Clinton.Trump revived the birther controversy on Thursday in an interview with The Washington Post when he declined to say whether he believed Obama was born in Hawaii.    Trump had promised ""a big announcement"" about the birther issue on Friday
column17: giving the impression it was the purpose of the event at his hotel. Instead
column18: he held off saying anything about it through more than 20 minutes of endorsements from military veterans. Only then did Trump make a brief statement about Obama's birth.Trump devoted more time at the beginning of the event to talking about his hotel where the event took place. He ignored reporters' shouted questions. (Additional reporting by Amanda Becker
column20: Susan Heavey and Jeff Mason; Writing by John Whitesides; Editing by Jonathan Oatis and Leslie Adler)"

column1: 3	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-michelleobama-idUSKCN11M2GB	Popular Michelle Obama courts young people for Clinton	"
By Jeff Mason
| FAIRFAX
column2: Va.

column1: FAIRFAX
column2: Va. Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton's campaign deployed a popular surrogate on Friday to gin up enthusiasm amid young voters who could be critical to victory on Nov. 8: Michelle Obama.The U.S. first lady and wife of President Barack Obama
column3: who won the White House in 2008 and 2012 with high levels of support from young voters
column4: told a crowd of students in Virginia that they could mean the difference between a Clinton win or a loss to Republican nominee Donald Trump.""Let's be clear
column5: elections aren't just about who votes
column6: but who doesn't vote. And that is especially true for young people like all of you
column8: noting that voters under the age of 30 provided the margin of victory for Obama in the swing states of Ohio
column10: Florida and Virginia in 2012.""Without those votes
column11: Barack would have lost those states and he definitely would have lost that election. Period
column13: she said.A New York Times/CBS poll this week showed Clinton with more support from people under 30 than Trump but still well below the levels Obama achieved.

column1: Though she has not yet been a frequent presence on the 2016 campaign trail
column2: Mrs. Obama has proven to be an especially powerful advocate for Clinton
column3: her husband's one-time rival. Her speech in support of Clinton at the Democratic convention in July was praised as one of the best of that event.""I'm inspired
column4: she said
column5: listing Clinton's positions in public service and rejecting arguments that Clinton was not an inspiring figure. The current first lady praised the former first lady as one of the most qualified people for the office of president in history.""So we cannot afford to squander this opportunity
column6: particularly given the alternative. Because here is what we know: that being president isn't anything like reality TV

column1: A president could not just ""pop off"" when making life or death decisions about war and peace
column2: she said without naming Trump.  Mrs. Obama noted that the country was in a time of transition
column3: just like her family
column4: which was about to move into a new house. She joked that they had to make sure the White House was cleaned up so they could get their security deposit back.

column1: Then she referred to the transition in 2008 with a dig at Trump for questioning whether Barack Obama was born in Hawaii. On Friday he finally conceded that Obama was U.S. born.""There were those who questioned
column2: and continued to question for the past eight years
column3: up through this very day
column4: whether my husband was even born in this country
column5: she said to boos.""I think Barack has answered those questions with the example he's set: by going high when they go low.""  (Reporting by Jeff Mason; Editing by Chris Reese)"

column1: 4	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-debate-idUSKCN11M270	U.S. presidential debate rules out third party candidates	"
WASHINGTON Libertarian Party presidential candidate Gary Johnson and Green Party hopeful Jill Stein have failed to quality for the first planned U.S. presidential debate on Sept. 26
column2: the Commission on Presidential Debates said on Friday.The commission
column3: citing the averages the various candidates have achieved in selected polls
column4: confirmed that Republican Donald Trump and Democrat Hillary Clinton had met the criteria.It also said that the vice presidential running mates of the two leading candidates were the only two to qualify for the vice presidential debate set for Oct. 4.The first presidential debate will be held at Hofstra University in Hempstead
column5: New York and the vice presidential debate at Longwood University in Farmville
column6: Virginia.Using the average of five national polls
column10: the commission said. Selection for the debates requires at least 15 percent support.

column1: Johnson and Stein were both constitutionally eligible and had ballot access in enough states to theoretically win an electoral college majority
column2: but missed the polling threshold.Stein's campaign website said she and her running mate Ajamu Baraka will both attend the first presidential debate
column3: and urged supporters to join them. The campaign said it might ask supporters to attempt to escort the candidates into the debate in an action that ""may lead to arrest -- it is possible but not definite. There will be actions you can take with us at Hofstra that do not risk arrest.""

column1: The campaign said it is ""organizing nonviolent civil resistance training for this.""Johnson said in a statement that: ""I would say I'm surprised that the CPD has chosen to exclude me from the first debate
column2: but I'm not.""

column1: The commission was a private organization created by the Republican and Democratic parties ""for the clear purpose of taking control of the only nationally televised presidential debates voters will see
column2: Johnson said.The last time a third-party candidate was allowed to participate in the televised debates was in 1992
column3: when Ross Perot met the requirements running as an independent. (Reporting by Timothy Ahmann and Eric Walsh; Editing by David Gregorio)"

column1: 5	http://reuters.com/article/us-soccer-france-idUSKCN11M2F7	Cavani strikes back with four goals as PSG sink Caen	"
PARIS Edinson Cavani silenced his critics when he scored four goals in Paris St Germain's 6-0 victory at Caen in Ligue 1 on Friday.    The Uruguay striker
column2: who wasted a handful of chances in the French champions' 1-1 home draw against Arsenal in the Champions League on Tuesday
column3: found the back of the net four times before the break in a one-sided encounter.    The result meant that PSG
column4: who had bagged only one point from their last two league encounters
column5: move to the top of the standings with 10 points from five games.   Monaco
column8: could take over at the top depending on Saturday's results.

column1: Cavani opened the scoring after 12 minutes when he latched onto a Maxwell cross from the left and doubled the tally from the penalty spot after Syam Ben Youssef fouled Lucas in the box.Maxwell again set up Cavani for the third
column2: the forward tapping in from a cross at the near post seven minutes from the break.   Cavani added a fourth on the stroke of halftime
column3: poking the ball home from Thomas Meunier's cross.

column1: Unai Emery's side's domination continued after the break as Lucas fired home from just outside the box in the 67th.   Forward Jean-Kevin Augustin added a sixth
column2: converting Adrien Radiot's assist 11 minutes from time.

column1: Monaco take on Stade Rennais and Bordeaux host Angers on Saturday. (Reporting by Julien Pretot
column2: editing by Pritha Sarkar)"

column1: 6	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-trade-idUSKCN11M1JK	Obama enlists Republican Kasich to push for TPP trade deal	"
By Roberta Rampton
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON Ohio's Republican governor
column2: John Kasich
column3: took over the White House briefing lectern on Friday to praise the 12-nation Trans-Pacific Partnership
column4: an unusual move that shows how hard President Barack Obama will push for the trade deal's approval.Obama
column5: a Democrat who is leaving office in four months
column7: who fell short in his bid to be the Republican presidential candidate
column8: in the White House Oval Office to discuss strategies for overcoming domestic political angst over the TPP.The unlikely partnership comes as the White House makes a final full-court push to persuade Republican congressional leaders to approve the deal in a ""lame duck"" session after the Nov. 8 election. Both Republican and Democratic candidates have pilloried the TPP.""We cannot get to the point in America that because a Democrat wants something
column10: Kasich said in an impassioned plea to Republican lawmakers to back the deal
column11: which is a key part of Obama's foreign policy legacy.Kasich said the deal is vital for the U.S. economy and also to counter China and Russia
column12: and said business leaders need to apply pressure on lawmakers to approve it.""Right now
column13: China is pushing hard to create their own trade agreement
column14: Obama told reporters in the Oval Office ahead of the meeting
column15: saying U.S. businesses were at risk of being ""cut out"" of Asia

column1: I promise you that China's not going to be setting up a bunch of rules that are going to be to the advantage of American companies and American businesses
column2: Obama said.Other business and political leaders also attended the meeting
column3: including former Republican Treasury Secretary Henry Paulson
column4: International Business Machines Corp Chief Executive Officer Virginia Rometty and former New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg.Republicans traditionally have backed free trade deals
column7: has blamed the agreements for U.S. job losses and threatened to tear them up should he win.

column1: Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has said the TPP would not get a Senate vote this year
column2: and House of Representatives Speaker Paul Ryan has said he does not see enough votes for it to pass.Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton has also opposed the deal
column3: which is unpopular with labor unions and environmental groups.Obama has said he hopes opposition cools after the election. The White House has pointed to opinion polls showing most Americans support trade as a sign that the TPP could still squeak through Congress.

column1: If you're frustrated about rules of trade that disadvantage America
column2: if you're frustrated about jobs being shipped overseas ... then you want to get this thing passed
column3: Obama told reporters.On his final trip to Asia as president earlier this month
column4: Obama spent time reassuring nervous partners that the United States would finalize the TPP. But on Friday
column5: Vietnam's parliament indicated it would not ratify the deal quickly.White House spokesman Josh Earnest said Vietnam's decision was not a setback. ""I think the real stumbling block
column7: the obstacle here is (the U.S.) Congress
column9: noting there was ""every indication"" that Vietnam would proceed as long as Congress approved the TPP. (Reporting by Roberta Rampton; Additional reporting by Ayesha Rascoe; Editing by Jonathan Oatis and Leslie Adler)"

column1: 7	http://reuters.com/article/us-mexico-drugs-california-idUSKCN11L2VE	Mexico president following California marijuana vote: state lawmaker	"
By Gabriel Stargardter
(This Sept 15 story corrects ""asked"" in first paragraph to ""raised with"" California lawmakers)By Gabriel StargardterMEXICO CITY Mexican President Enrique Pena Nieto
column2: who has proposed liberalizing his country's drug laws
column3: privately raised with California lawmakers visiting Mexico a state measure to legalize recreational marijuana
column4: a state legislator said on Thursday.A delegation of California Democratic lawmakers visiting Mexico talked for an hour on Wednesday with Pena Nieto about trade and the state's border with Mexico.During the meeting
column5: Pena Nieto brought up the November ballot measure without getting into details
column6: California state Senator Ben Allen said in an interview.""But they're clearly paying close attention

column1: If California votes to create a legal cannabis market
column2: it would place great pressure on Mexico
column3: which is mired in combating its vast drug-trafficking networks
column4: to follow suit. There was no mention of the California marijuana initiative in the presidency's report on the meeting
column5: and Pena Nieto's office did not immediately respond to request for comment.Pena Nieto has said the United States and Mexico should not pursue diverging policies on marijuana legislation and in April proposed a bill to allow Mexicans to carry up to an ounce of marijuana has stalled in Congress.

column1: California's proposal would allow people over 21 years to possess up to an ounce of marijuana for private use and establish a system to license
column2: regulate and tax sales of cannabis. Recent polls show a majority of Californians favor legalizing marijuana.

column1: Four U.S. states plus the District of Columbia already allow recreational use for adults. Voters in several more states
column2: including the southern border state of Arizona
column3: will consider similar legislation in November.Long regarded as a conservative on drug policy
column4: Pena Nieto has modified his stance since he took office in 2012
column5: reflecting growing Latin American disenchantment with the war on drugs. A bill to legalize medical marijuana remains in Congress. Ethan Nadelmann
column6: the executive director of the Drug Policy Alliance
column7: said he eventually expects Mexico to be swayed by the fiscal opportunities of regulated cannabis
column8: which he believes could earn California around $1 billion a year in tax revenue. (Reporting by Gabriel Stargardter; Editing by Cynthia Osterman)"

column1: 8	http://reuters.com/article/us-wells-fargo-accounts-congress-idUSKCN11M1VZ	House committee to hold hearing on Wells Fargo sales practices	"

WASHINGTON The U.S. House Financial Services Committee has opened a probe into Wells Fargo's sales practices and plans to call the company's chief executive before lawmakers at a hearing later in September
column2: the committee chairman said on Friday.Wells Fargo has settled with regulators over allegations that its staff opened more than two million bank accounts and credit cards for customers without their consent to meet internal sales goals. As part of last week's settlement
column3: Wells Fargo agreed to pay $185 million in penalties and $5 million to customers.

column1: Committee Chairman Representative Jeb Hensarling said the committee was ""requesting all records related to the allegations of fraudulent or improper activity by Wells Fargo employees"" from the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection and the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency
column2: and also requested records from the company.

column1: (Reporting by Susan Heavey)"
